qas.question: What is most popular alcoholic drink in the world?
What is believed to be the oldest alcoholic drinking the world?
What is the term used to describe the making beer?
What brewing process naturally carbonates beer?
What prayer did people use in Mesopotamia to remember a beer recipe?
What is the oldest drink in the world?
What is all beer flavoured with?
What starch is always used in the fermentation process?
What is the prayer in the Code of Hammurabi?
Who is the world's goddess of beer?
What two drinks follow beer as the most popular?
What involves the fermentation of hops?

plausible_answers.text: malted barley, although wheat, maize (corn), and rice

qas.question: What types of cereal grains is beer flavored with?

plausible_answers.text: laws regulating beer and beer parlours

qas.question: What did the Code of Ninkasi include?

plausible_answers.text: a prayer to the Mesopotamian goddess of beer

qas.question: What is The Hymn to Haammurabi?

context: <a0_0><a1_0><b5_0>Beer<b5_0/><a1_0/><a0_0/> is the world's most widely consumed and likely the oldest alcoholic beverage; it is the third most popular drink overall, after <b10_0>water and tea<b10_0/>. The production of beer is called <a2_0><b11_0>brewing<b11_0/><a2_0/>, which involves the fermentation of starches, mainly derived from cereal grains—most commonly <b7_0><b12_0>malted barley<b7_0/>, although wheat, maize (corn), and rice<b12_0/> are widely used. Most beer is flavoured with <b6_0>hops<b6_0/>, which add bitterness and act as a natural preservative, though other flavourings such as herbs or fruit may occasionally be included. The <a3_0>fermentation<a3_0/> process causes a natural carbonation effect which is often removed during processing, and replaced with forced carbonation. Some of humanity's earliest known writings refer to the production and distribution of beer: the Code of Hammurabi included <b13_0>laws regulating beer and beer parlours<b13_0/>, and "<a4_0><b8_0>The Hymn to <b9_0>Ninkasi<b9_0/><b8_0/><a4_0/>", <b14_0>a prayer to the Mesopotamian goddess of beer<b14_0/>, served as both a prayer and as a method of remembering the recipe for beer in a culture with few literate people.
